text:
RAVEL: CMS.801 is a required
course for master's students in

the Comparative Media Studies
Program.

They ideally take it in the
first semester of their second

year.
And the goal of the class is to

provide them with some
historical depth and perspective

on media change.
In other words,

most of these students come to
the program with some background

in a media industry or with an
undergraduate degree in which

they have majored in a series of
studies that is relevant to CMS.

But many of them don't have
that kind of historical

perspective.
And the goal of the class is to

look at earlier points of media
change.

In the version of the class
that I teach,

we began with the transition
from scrolls to codex books,

in other words,
the book as we know it today,

which takes place around 400
AD.

And we move forward through the
advent of the printing press in

Europe.
In the 19th century,

we talk about the beginnings of
photography, radio,

various sound technologies.
And, in the version of the

course that I taught,
we end with early film.

And the point is for students
who are hyper-aware of media

change today,
as a result of the digital

revolution, to have a
comparative perspective so they

can get a better sense of what
really is new,

revolutionary,
radical and what has been seen

and done before.
It is kind of the historian's

conceit.
I am a historian by training,

and it is kind of the
historian's conceit to say there

are no new things under the sun.
Students in this class are

evaluated based on their class
participation.

It is a three hour a week
seminar, and it met in the

evenings in the fall of 2004.
And class participation is

absolutely vital.
This is not a lecture class.

In some instances,
particularly in earlier

historical periods where
students might not have much

background, I will provide maybe
a ten or fifteen minute

mini-lecture to give them the
historical context for the

readings that we have done.
But, by and large,

it is a discussion.
So part of the evaluation

method is simply their
contribution to the class

discussion.
Each student also has the

opportunity, either by
themselves or sometimes in

tandem with another classmate to
lead a discussion.

That is probably not the right
term.

To make a presentation based on
that week's readings which will

both summarize and also pose
provocative questions to get the

discussion rolling.
The presentations were often

quite interesting,
involved PowerPoint

presentations or the use of
websites.

They were multi-media
experiences themselves.

And then finally,
in addition to class

participation and the one
presentation,

the students wrote a 20 page
paper at the end of the

semester.
I offered them the opportunity

to submit a final project in
some format other than the

traditional hardcopy paper.
Interestingly enough none of

the students took me up on that
this term.

My goal, in teaching the class,
was always to respect the

integrity and the totality of
the past to try to place media

change in as much context as
possible.

And, in so doing,
to think about similarities and

differences, not just between
the media change itself,

but also between the cultural,
social, political,

economic context in which these
media changes were taking place.

Course material of CMS.801 fits
into the CMS,

the Comparative Media Studies
program in the following way.

First of all,
remember that this is a

graduate level course.
By the time the students come

to this class they have already
taken, done a year of coursework

at MIT, and they have had
required courses in media theory

and practice.
And I believe also in some

technological aspects of various
media industries.

So my goal is really to
complement the more contemporary

aspects of the class by
providing historical dimension.

That is not to say the class is
atheoretical.

We began as browsers of the
website, we will see,

by reading the book by Walter
Ong, "Orality and Literacy:

The Technologizing of the
Word."

In that same week we read
Marshall McLuhan's

"Understanding Media [Change?]."
Two very different perspectives

on media but using them in an
effort to provide a kind of

theoretical framework or,
in some cases,

just punching bags for us to
bounce off and be in dialogue

with for the rest of the term.
Well, the sort of day-to-day

life of CMS.801,
I really actually prefer to

think of it in sort of weekly
units.

We have an email discussion
list.

And, in some weeks during the
fall 2004 semester,

that discussion list was quite
active with people exchanging

ideas about readings or passing
on URLs of articles and things

they would come across online
that they thought were relevant

to our class discussion.
So the discussion continues at

perhaps a less intense level
outside of the three hours that

we meet every week as well.
Within the three hour class,

the pattern typically is I will
begin with a few administrative

announcements,
and then I turn things over to

the student or students who are
presenting that material that

week.
And it was very interesting the

pattern that student
presentations took during the

course of the term.
As the semester went on the

presentations got lengthier and
lengthier.

And, in response,
the rest of the students and

myself also began to intervene
in the presentations to ask

questions to say,
well, how does this relate to

what we read two weeks ago?
And, by the end of the term,

the presentations basically
were the whole three hour

session.
And it was very hard for the

presenters to get a word in
edgewise after they had begun

their initial presentation.
So it was that kind of a class
dynamic.
